Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Engineering Students in the East Tennessee Demographic Region

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Current projections indicate that the demand for U.S. graduates in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields in the upcoming decades exceeds the supply, more U.S. graduates need to be produced in these fields. In addition, diversity is one of the keys to national success in the technological workforce, since the protocols of today require teams with members having diverse viewpoints and backgrounds to perform the demanding and complex engineering tasks required in global capital markets. This project is addressing these issues by creating a systematic, goal-oriented program aimed directly at increasing the number, and also the diversity, of majors in the College of Engineering at the university. The STEM industries being targeted are those which are well represented within the less technologically advanced southeastern region of the U.S.

Intellectual Merit:
Scholarships are being provided to well-qualified, financially needy students from all demographic groups to pursue B.S. degrees in Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, Computer Engineering, and Materials Science and Engineering. Scholarship students who would not otherwise be able to afford a university education are recrutied and selected, with a focus on increasing the diversity of the national pool of engineers.

The specific program goals are to:
a) provide at least 80% of the necessary financial support for at least 30 students from diverse backgrounds.
b) provide these students with a rich educational opportunity, through academic, research, and industrial co-op experiences.
c) retain at least 95% of these students until degree attainment.
d) place at least 20% of these students into internationally recognized, top-tier graduate programs in the STEM fields.
e) place the remainder of these students into industrial positions, particularly within the southeastern region of the U.S.
f) catalyze an immediate and long-term expansion in the diversity of the engineering workforce in the targeted industries.

Broader Impacts:
The primary broader impact is a diversification of the technological workforce in U.S. industries, with particularly emphasis on those located within the economically depressed southeastern region of the nation. This is leading to an engineering community that is better able to introduce innovative ideas, designs, and products that allow U.S. industries to compete effectively in the ever-changing global marketplace of the present and future. A secondary broader impact is to place graduating students into international corporations within the southeastern region of the nation, wherein they can quickly rise to positions in which their own diverse viewpoints can positively impact those corporations. Another broader impact of the program is to develop and improve a model for diversifying STEM education that can be replicated at universities throughout the southeastern region of the U.S., and to disseminate the results of this effort through appropriate venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current projections indicate that the demand for U.S. graduates in STEM fields in the upcoming decades will far exceed the supply. Furthermore, the projections indicate that the number of scientists and engineers from underrepresented groups will decline, rather than increase. Since these fields are critical to the economy and technological needs of the nation, it is essential that dramatic steps be taken now to address these issues. More U.S. graduates need to be produced in these fields, and, in particular, the diversity of the STEM workforce needs to be substantially increased.

Specific project objectives were: 1) to provide scholarships for academically talented but financially challenged students to attend the College of Engineering; 2) to provide resources to help them achieve their academic goals; 3) to provide coop and research experiences to guide their career choices. Requirements for continuation in the program were: students must remain enrolled in one of the targeted disciplines (Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, Computer Engineering); students must continue to make reasonable progress towards their degrees; students must maintain a 2.75 GPA.

S-STEM Scholarships were awarded to a total of 60 students primarily from the East Tennessee geographic region, of which about 37% were women, over five years. Programming elements for students included:

  • Attendance at a cohort orientation meetings;
  • Students met with their S-STEM advisors during October and March of their first two years of study;
  • Students kept their S-STEM advisors appraised of any academic or personal issues;
  • Students participated in infrequent programmatic events, such as social or outreach activities.

A total of 60 students participated in the program in one of the three cohorts. Of these, 34 have already graduated and another 15 will graduate by spring 2019. Five students left the program due to poor academic performance (3) or a change of major outside of the targeted discipline (2). All remaining students will have graduated by spring of 2020. Graduation dates have been delayed for some students who chose to take coop assignments and internships. Although all of the students have not yet graduated, the odds are very high that those now remaining will sustain their effort until they do since most attrition in the college is during the first two years of study. Therefore, the projected graduation rate is about 92%, which is respectful although not the full 100% that we had originally hoped for. Only 15% (rather than the hoped for 30%) of students went on to graduate or professional school; unfortunately, the very healthy job market made it difficult for our students to turn down lucrative industrial careers for a long-term payoff from graduate school. Still, however, 15% is higher than (about double) the average rate from the College of Engineering.

There are some interesting conclusions resulting from this project. The primary one is that, on the whole, the program has tended to equalize all of the students. First generation and non-first generation students perform about the same, using GPA as a measure of performance. Males and females also graduate with the same mean GPA. Furthermore, when comparing the GPAs of graduating students in Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Computer Science, again the mean GPAs are essentially the same. The only area where there is a difference is in race: all races other than African-Americans had similar mean GPAs. However, the mean GPA for African-American students was skewed somewhat because of several students who ultimately dropped out of the program with very low GPAs. Of graduating students, African-American students averaged out similarly to students of other races. The takeaway from this seems to be that African-American students tend to drop out at a higher rate than other races; however, there are many factors that could impact this conclusion, but the sample size in the present study is too small to analyze these in any detail.

Overall, the S-STEM Scholarship Program has succeeded in its primary goal, which was to enable academically talented students to achieve their dreams of an undergraduate education in engineering and to move on to the next stage of their careers. With a > 90% graduation rate from all cohorts, the program appears to have been effective at retaining students by keeping them motivated, providing outside opportunities for paid work experiences (35% of students participating in coops), and providing academic monitoring and assistance, as well as emotional support. On the whole, the program management feels that creating a sense of shared community is a very important factor in the high retention rate affected by the program.
